The core mechanic is brilliant: your buildings only work when you look at them. Your "gaze" is a literal beam of light on the grid. If you aren't looking at the farm, no food is produced. If you aren't looking at the barracks, no soldiers are trained.

Why it's addictive:
Constant Vigilance: You have to constantly sweep your vision across your kingdom to keep the economy flowing. It’s a high-pressure test of your attention management.

The "One More Run" Factor: It’s a roguelite. You will die, upgrade your castle/stats, and jump right back in to try a new strategy.

Visuals: Clean, charming pixel art that remains readable even when the screen is full of enemies.

Cons: No save & quit feature during a run (yet). You need to commit 30-45 mins per session.

Verdict:
If you enjoy optimizing workflows and panicked resource management, this is a must-buy. Simple to understand, hard to master, and impossible to put down.

Easily one of the most innovative "Tower Defence" style games I've played.

It achieves that, by combining the following elements:
1. The "King's Gaze" — which also explains the title's "The King is WATCHING" part — which allows building inside your base to become activated
2. Individual kings with their abilities and passive effects, and most importantly, with their individual gaze
3. Various spells that affect your base, your units, or the enemies
4. A plethora of units with their pros and cons, active and passive abilities, allowing for various combinations
5. Advisors, who essentially offer additional bonuses, who add another layer of complexity
6. Upgrades and unlocks for new buildings, units, spell damage, etc

All these serve one purpose: to ensure that your small kingdom is safeguarded against wave after wave of monstrous enemies. And I'm not even counting the many modifications tied to the map, which modifies the enemies spawned, as well as the bosses, coupled with the difficulty levels.

For its price, the game is worth it. Although there are only 2 levels available (a 3rd on the making), and around 6 kings to choose from, if you're into "Tower Defence", you will love it. The developers have created something unique. And uniqueness should be awarded.

TL;DR: The King Is Watching is witty, elegant, strategic, addictive and somehow endlessly fresh. 

I don’t write reviews. I don’t even finish games. Yet here I am, not only having 100% completed The King Is Watching, but immediately launching run after run like a medieval lab rat who refuses to leave the maze.
What makes it so good?
Well, it’s delightfully deceptive. It looks simple — a few resource tracks, a charming medieval vibe, and a king who stares at you like he knows you’re about to mess something up. But under the hood? It’s a low-barrier-to-entry, sky-high-skill-ceiling machine. Anyone can start a run in seconds… but mastering it feels like earning a PhD in Kingdom Mismanagement.
The magic is in the balance.
There’s just enough randomness to keep you on your toes, but enough predictability that it never feels unfair. The scenarios are humorous without being silly and the whole game has that perfect “I can definitely do better next time” energy that eats entire evenings.
And the artefacts?
Genuinely brilliant.
Some of them are absolute pants — the kind of relics that make you stare at the screen and mutter, “Well… that’s the run ruined.” But that’s exactly why the good ones feel so good. When you find an artefact that transforms your whole run, you feel it — suddenly you're adapting your entire strategy, leaning into new synergies, and pretending this was your plan all along.
Unlike most roguelites, the early game never becomes boring.
I don’t know how they’ve done it, but even after tens of hours, the first few minutes of a run are still interesting. No autopilot. No slog. No “here we go again” start. Each run feels like a fresh little puzzle you want to poke at.
Compared to other roguelites like Nuclear Throne or Void War, this game sits in a beautiful sweet spot:
easier to pick up,
harder to master,
shorter runs when you want them,
brutal long grinds when you don’t realise lunch became dinner.

And then there’s the crown jewels:
The challenges and that cursed, stubborn, infuriating Deforestation challenge.
I swear this achievement is personally mocking me. I’ve spent hours chasing it, convinced the stars would align. When I finally got it? I celebrated like I’d won a Nobel Prize… and then immediately started another run because apparently I enjoy suffering.

Long live the King.
And long live my inability to stop playing this perfect little game.

I picked this up expecting a chill rogue-like, and honestly? It’s surprisingly really fun. Instead of the usual button-mashing, this one leans more into strategy — and the core mechanic is genius. Your kingdom literally doesn’t function unless the king’s eyes are on it, and that idea shapes everything you do. It’s weird, clever, and way more addictive than I anticipated.

You start with simple, almost bare-bones builds — just enough to maybe scrape your way to the first boss. But the moment you fall (and you will), the game opens up. Suddenly there’s a whole upgrade tree for the king’s “eyes”: more troops, more build options, more variety. The early RNG is limited because of that progression path, but it feels intentional — like the game is teaching you its rules before letting you break them.

For the price, the replayability is honestly impressive. There’s just enough randomness to make every run feel different, but not so much that you’re relying on luck. It’s refreshing to see a smaller developer put out something this polished, strategic, and charming.

Hopefully future updates bring even more variety — expanded upgrade trees, additional counsel members, new kings, and definitely more locations and bosses. The foundation is strong enough that DLC or content patches could make this game explode in the best way.

If you want a calmer rogue-like with smart mechanics and satisfying growth, this one is absolutely worth supporting.

So I just finished this game 100% and wanted to share some thoughts in the case any dev ever reads this, if you are looking at this and asking yourself if you should give it a try then the answer is definitly YES, it is a fantastic game and you should definitly try the demo (it still shows up when I search for it but it doesnt send me to its page but the main game site? hopefully it gets fixed).

Dont take this in a negative way, it just comes much easier to me to point out lacking points/things that could be improved rather than naming the positive points (which the biggest part of the game is) and the fact that I thought the game was good enough for me to 100% it should speak for itself:

1. Like most roguelikes, this game also features different "ascension levels" which increases the difficulty of the game each time and you unlock the next upon beating the last one. There are a total of 10 different ones, with 3 being the "neutral" one where neither the player nor the enemy gets any buffs. Now there are 2 of the 10 that feel really bad. namely the 6th and the 10th. The  6th one is boring because the enemy just gets 40% more hp with no cool twist on the game mechanics or other stuff like the other levels before. But the worst is definitly the 10th. Not only is the added difficuly of the final level just the enemy getting more hp and more dmg, but it just REMOVES the added diffculty of the 9th lvl, being the player unable to move building once placed. It just kinda feels bad to reach the final difficulty and then you see what it actually does (also would be nice if difficulty would carry over between the different maps so you dont have to grind through the lower levels just to try the highest difficulty if you already reached that on the other map)

2. Regarding boss design, it really feels bad that basically all t1/t2 bosses have massiv aoe attacks (especially on the graveyard map) this means on higher difficulty many of the melee or even range units become useless since they would just get onetapped by the boss. So the player focuses heavily on single tanky units which kinda ruins build differsity and makes many runs feels sameish.

3. It would be really nice to have a buildable undead unit for veteran/elite tier. Playing alucard on lower difficulty feels ok and you can simply amass and upgrade your undead with his abilites and reach critical mass, but on higher difficulties they die very easily. To reach t4 undead you need to use his second ability 3 times on the same units but they just die so easily since the lower tier ones are all melee. Having a recruitable higher undead unit on which you then could use your ability would make upgrading them much easiert (sure on graveyard you can buy middle tier undead in the graveyard shop but even then it doesnt feel good and it just feels bad to have one king be so heavily restriced into one map).

4. For multiple kings, the last vision vision uprade (Spellus and Wise, for Saladin even the TWO last) are way too expensive and there is literally no reason to ever buy them instead of building "monomunt of the kings's gaze" to increase vision radius.

5. Like for any kind of roguelikes, I really wish you could choose certain things (lets say for this game 3 buildings, 3 spells and 3 relics) to not show up during a run. There are always certain things I never use, even in the 50h hours of playing this game and it feels always bad if this shows up (especially bad for legendary relics, which you only get very few per run and which you cannot reroll. and then you have to choose between 2 that buffs spells,,,when you dont even use spells most of the times).

6. Clay really feels like a useless resource. besides the 2. vision upgrade which is mandatory for each king, it is only really used to build 2 units. Its theoretical main use is to repair your city walls but the thing is, if you even get dmg to your city walls (besides early game) you are already dead in 90% of the cases so reparing it afterwards would never matter really. The only king that really uses it is Spellus since he needs way more of it for his vision upgrades and patricius (one of the units that needs the resource) is a really good tank for this king.

7. While the ingame wiki is really well made and you even can access it during a run, I reaaaly wish it would also list all spells/artifacts/non-building-recruitable-unit like enemy units or the undead alucard can summon.

8. This one is more like a wish from me: add a legendary smithy like building that can craft building upgrades/artifacts so you can really craft everthing ingame and dont need that shop for anything.

After 20 hours, even though I don't feel like making a review, I feel like I have to give this the roguelike, auto sim itch that is becoming so popular. Good sprites, interesting mechanics that feel opportunity fulfilling, simple gameplay. But, optimization may be too open to interpretation. Obviously, meta and builds will inevitably make their way to some forum or another, but solving the riddle on my own feels much more satisfying. This game makes it feel like chasing the dragon, always nearby but forever out of reach.  Do I feel proud about my effort or dedication? No, I don't. Is the game entertaining enough to offer another 20 hours of "fun." Yes, of that I have no doubt.

I didn't feel as guilty as I did optimizing builds in balatro. That just felt like gambling. But its no where near as satisfying as slay the spire or monster train (2). Probably because of how RNG is implemented. There are so many different unit types, upgrades, and production buildings that there might be too many options to navigate the easily 30+ minute matches. Often getting units completely unrelated to what you've built around producing with few, very few, opportunities to reorganize relatively expensive building infrastructure systems. Such as oil production, grapes, wheat to flours, and meat. They are deep-ish, but inconsistent because of limitations of rerolls and, ironically, the need to build infrastructure specifically around the 'shop' currency. ( in game, not at all real money )

Enemies, all look great and there are as many as their are available units. After 20 hours, I couldn't tell you the different between one and another aside from ranged or melee. Big, melee. Staff, range. The bosses are there too, and sometimes they are difficult. Not much else there. Big auto army goes into other big auto army. The only rule really seems to be get a frontline, get a backline, and hope you get a couple upgrades for those units. ( Felt like about 33% drops for useful units )

Also, the different kings have different upgrade 'sight ranges' this is pretty interesting as builds can vary greatly. Unfortunately, certain kings start out not-so-great and on the harder difficulties the cost for wasting time clearing areas just becomes quite imbalanced.

What would happen if Balatro and Stronghold had a child? You can probably see how stupendously great their baby would be, in the eyes of the King on the cover. That's also me, staring at this glorious pixel art game. Dirty and retro inspired for battle, extravagant and surreal outside of it.

I really love how the game treats me, how it increases difficulty levels, prompting me, to be more inventive, if not with a challenge, then by throwing an artefact my way. It feels, at times, as a board game, where you progress through a single board, yet every game is slightly richer, due to achievements and awards. Threat Level 3, is where you swap the board, meaning you unlocked all of it, except its difficulties, so the game only starts. 
At this point, I'm still yet to achieve that, but as a 15 EUR worth game it already paid off.

Special mention prize: the music, that prompts your eyes to gaze, but like do it for real, dive into a tunnel with wells and farms, sweaty rhythm pulsing through your veins with impatience. Music morphs into combat and reading states, even if somewhat roughly, but otherwise attentively to you, the player.

The gaze mechanic and tile placement are somewhat superficial to me. Yes, they add to the challenge and require some thought, but I think the real crux of this game is risk management. The most important choices are multiple-choice, from a few randomly-selected options. 

When you pick what enemies you'll face, you don't know what troops and resources you'll have by the time they arrive. You can significantly influence the difficulty, but if you go too easy you won't get enough rewards to prepare you for future waves.

You need troops to survive, but when picking troop building blueprints you often don't know if/when you'll get the resources needed to build the building or train the troops. The game doesn't cut you much slack - if you gamble on a blueprint that needs a less common resource and don't get it in time, your run could be doomed.  

However, there is a limited currency for rerolls, and meta-game progression makes things a lot easier. 

On lower threat levels I'd say it's a great casual game. After that, the difficulty ramps up sharply and it starts to feel frustrating to lose late in a run. Still, I'm overall enjoying my time with it.

Even if I quit now I'd have gotten my money's worth, but I think it'll be worth grinding a bit to see what happens when I unlock more.

Wonderful take on the roguelite base-builder/tower defense genre (mashup?). The only thing really close to this that I can think of is Super Fantasy Kingdom (which is also very new) and Nordhold. Like the two aforementioned games, you use different currencies to build new buildings and draft units to defend against progressively stronger waves of enemies. The beauty of TKiW is that not every plot of your base works all the time. As the name implies The King is Watching...a handful of squares/plots. This means that the other plots are NOT working for you while you aren't "watching" them. You can freely rotate and move your gaze AND push-pause whenever you like, which you will be doing a ton. You can also speed up time which comes in handy towards the end of most runs when you are just churning out units and resources. The micromanaging aspect of watching tiles to get them to work, coupled with the massive amount of unlockable buildings and units makes this game extremely fun. Usually micormanaging is a used as a negative connotation, but I think with TKiW it's a great thing. With most city saver games (I just coined that term tyvm), micromanaging IS the "thing" you do and what makes it fun!


Anyways, I'd say TKiW is one of the most unique games i've played and I can't recommend it enough! The art and cute little story really make the game shine too. Did I mention the unlockables? There's SOOOO many and the rate of unlocking things is JUST right imo. Also, I finally unlocked the graveyard map after about....I'd say 20 hours of playtime maybe. - Army size is more important than army quality early on.
- Don't be afraid to demolish buildings (especially weak troops) if you need space for something better.

I'm still fighting the same combinations of six bosses, two at each stage.  I'm still fighting the same enemies which don't have much to distinguish themselves.  I'm still using the same units because more interesting units take more complex resources, which take production chains, which you'd think would be interesting to create but it's pretty random which resources you can generate.

And the gameplay loop itself ends up being incredibly repetitive because the fights are not balanced.  You can, to an extent, choose whether you want to make the next round of fights impossibly difficult or easy as cake, but you can only guess whether you have gone too far. I want to like this game, and I do for a lot of reasons, but I would not recommend it.  The big problems are a lack of balance to make thing interesting, and a lack of variety in the early-game (I consider myself still early in the meta progression at about 11 hours).

When you start this game, you are locked in to only one set of all the variables that look like they will eventually become available.  You can only fight in the village.  You can only pick from one king (different abilities and buffs).  You can only have one advisor (a buff slot).  You find, after the tutorial playthrough, that all of this stuff is unlockable.  The problem is, the runs take a long time, and you don't get enough coins to unlock anything really, even after as many hours as I've put in.  I'm still fighting the same combinations of six bosses, two at each stage.  I'm still fighting the same enemies which don't have much to distinguish themselves.  I'm still using the same units because more interesting units take more complex resources, which take production chains, which you'd think would be interesting to create but it's pretty random which resources you can generate.

And the gameplay loop itself ends up being incredibly repetitive because the fights are not balanced.  You can, to an extent, choose whether you want to make the next round of fights impossibly difficult or easy as cake, but you can only guess whether you have gone too far.  If you have, your run is over, and you will have unlocked virtually nothing and want to turn the game off.  If you haven't, you get to keep doing that until you get to the level's boss, at which time you will almost certainly lose, have enough coins to unlock virtually nothing, and want to turn the game off.

Roguelites and roguelikes are cool, permadeath is cool, meta progression is cool, and this game blends a lot of interesting concepts.  The music is good, the aesthetic is good (even if some of the character portraits just look like boogers), and I enjoyed the time I spent playing it until I realized I wasn't going to end up liking it.  Maybe I'll be wrong though and will keep playing it despite not really enjoying it.  Who knows.  Who cares.
